sub_title: Scientific Software Developer at Software for Chemistry & Materials
summary: My background includes a strong proficiency in developing mathematical models and writing large computer codes applied to physical and chemical models. My programming skills include C/C++, Java, Python, Fortran (77-2013) languages, with considerable experience in high-performance computing. I have a large experience in software development to simulate a wide variety of physical problems, which span across electronic structure calculations, massive gene expression data analysis, structure-activity relationships, molecular fragmentation, laser-surfaces interactions and developing models for global optimization. I am very familiar with writing technical reports and scientific articles (20 papers with 270 citations to date), creating and giving technical presentations for international conferences and mentoring people.

projects: [{'title': 'WPP: Propagation of 3D wave packets with time-dependent potentials.', 'date': {'start': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'description': 'This is a package designed to simulate the dynamics of a wave-packet interacting with a time-dependent potential. The time-dependent Schrödinger equation is solved in a three-dimensional spatial grid by using a strategy based on the split operator method. It allows among other properties, the diagonalization of Hamiltonians up to 3 dimensions in the  SAE approximation. It includes, algorithms like imaginary time evolution, Lanczos diagonalization and filtering diagonalization. It allows the calculation of several observables such as, energy, dipole moment, average position, among others, to analyze obtained results.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Nestor', 'last_name': 'Aguirre', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Scientific Software Developer at Software for Chemistry & Materials'}]}, {'title': 'M3C: A software package designed to describe statistical fragmentation of molecules.', 'date': {'start': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 2014}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'description': 'The M3C (Microcanonical Metropolis Monte-Carlo) is a software package designed in the field of Computational Chemistry. It allows to study fragmentation processes induced by irradiation with high-energy beams of ions, electrons or photons, which is based on an semi-classical statistical mechanical description in combination with structural quantities from standard electronic-structure methods. It allows to obtain channels/species distributions (breaking graphs), theoretical mass spectra, among others.\n', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Nestor', 'last_name': 'Aguirre', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Scientific Software Developer at Software for Chemistry & Materials'}]}, {'title': 'ccdyn: Classical dynamics of helium nanodroplets', 'date': {'start': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 2012}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'description': 'This application allows to represent the helium droplets such as classical particles interacting through pairwise potential models, it is possible to include external potentials in order to simulate their interaction with surfaces by using periodic potential energy functions.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Nestor', 'last_name': 'Aguirre', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Scientific Software Developer at Software for Chemistry & Materials'}]}, {'title': 'SciFT: Scientific Fortran Tools', 'date': {'start': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 2008}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'description': 'The Scientific Fortran Tools (SciFT) is a numerical library for Fortran programmers. The library provides a wide range of mathematical routines such as random number generators, special functions, least-squares fitting, and several data structures like linked lists, vectors, maps, and graphs. It is fully written following an oriented object design, which allows to extend it easily for other applications. In particular, the projects WPP, M3C, and ccdyn use this library extensively to carry out the most expensive and complex calculations.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Nestor', 'last_name': 'Aguirre', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Scientific Software Developer at Software for Chemistry & Materials'}]}]
